name: Haoma

etymology.derivation: Related to Vedic Soma - common Indo-Iranian origin

description: Sacred plant central to Zoroastrian ritual, pressed to create divine drink. Haoma personified as yazata (divine being) - both plant and deity. Grants health, strength, victory over evil, and communion with Ahura Mazda. Likely Ephedra species from mountain regions.

ritualPreparation.gathering: Fresh haoma twigs collected from sacred mountain locations
ritualPreparation.purification: Plant and all implements ritually cleansed
ritualPreparation.prayers: Recitation of Avestan hymns (Yasna 9-11, the Hom Yasht)
ritualPreparation.pounding: Twigs pounded in stone mortar with crescent-shaped pestle
ritualPreparation.mixing: Combined with pure water and milk to create sacred drink
ritualPreparation.offering: First portion offered to sacred fire
ritualPreparation.libation: Remaining portion poured as offering to waters and earth

uses: Yasna ceremony - central to Zoroastrian liturgy
Fire worship - haoma offered to sacred flames
Priestly communion - mobeds drink haoma ritually
Victory rituals - invoking strength against Angra Mainyu
Healing ceremonies - haoma as divine medicine
Purification - haoma water sprinkled for cleansing
Seasonal festivals - Gahambars include haoma offering
rituals: Yasna ceremony - elaborate preparation and offering (3-4 hours)
Hom Yasht - hymns 9-11 of Yasna praising haoma
Fire temple service - daily haoma offerings to Atash Bahram
Gahambars - six seasonal festivals with haoma
Initiation - Navjote ceremony may include haoma blessing
Frashokereti preparation - haoma aids cosmic renewal

haomaDivinity.personification: Haoma as yazata (divine being) mediating between humans and Ahura Mazda
haomaDivinity.titles: First priest, first warrior, first healer
haomaDivinity.mythology: Legendary figures who prepared haoma: Vivanghan, Yima, Thraetaona
haomaDivinity.blessings: Grants righteousness, healing, protection, prophetic vision
haomaDivinity.nature: Both physical plant and transcendent spiritual reality

sacredSignificance: Haoma = bridge between material and spiritual worlds. Essential to Zoroastrian worship. Combats druj (evil) with asha (truth). Prepares souls for Frashokereti (final renewal). Yasna 9-11 describe haoma as king of plants, granter of all good.
culturalContext: Haoma practice continues in Parsi and Iranian Zoroastrian communities. Ephedra species from Iran used today. Shared Indo-Iranian heritage with Vedic soma. Some Zoroastrians use pomegranate twigs as substitute. Ancient practice preserved through oral transmission.
spiritualEffects: Communion with Ahura Mazda and yazatas
preparationMethods: Traditional Yasna: pound fresh Ephedra twigs in stone mortar
Mix with pure water and milk (or consecrated water)
Modern: small amount symbolically prepared by mobeds

growingConditions.species: Ephedra major, E. intermedia, E. procera
growingConditions.harvest: Fresh green twigs gathered with prayer

symbolicMeanings: Mountain origin = purity and height of asha
Green color = vitality and life force
Liquid = flowing grace of Ahura Mazda
Offering to fire = union of elements
Shared consumption = priestly and divine communion
safetyWarnings: Cardiovascular stimulant - avoid with heart conditions
Traditional ritual use is minimal amount
Do not use large medicinal doses without expert guidance
Banned or restricted in some countries
